question: Among Black adults with sickle cell trait, are HbA1c values lower than in those without the trait for the same fasting or 2-hour plasma glucose levels, indicating that HbA1c overestimates glycemic control in this group? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: These findings suggest that HbA1c may systematically underestimate past glycemia in black patients with SCT and may require further evaluation.
content.source_2: In models adjusted for key risk factors and using concurrent 2-hour glucose and HbA1c measurements from 2001, participants with SCT had higher HbA1c (mean, 5.65%) than those without SCT (mean, 5.35%), yielding a mean HbA1c difference of +0.30% (95% CI, +0.21% to +0.39%).
content.source_3: Conclusions and Relevance Among African Americans from 2 large, well-established cohorts, participants with SCT had lower levels of HbA1c at any given concentration of fasting or 2-hour glucose compared with participants without SCT.
content.source_4: Unadjusted generalized estimating equation analyses calibrated to fasting glucose showed that HbA1c values were higher among those with SCT (6.01%) compared with those without SCT (5.72%), for a mean HbA1c difference of +0.29% (95% CI, +0.23% to +0.35%).
